Alohamora.Name: Alohamora

'Oculas' in Latin means 'eyes' or 'to see'. The spell can either refer to 'buckskin', or buck-like attributes appearing. Or more vaguely, refers to something above the eyes-- where the spell appears to target.

Aparecium.Name: Aparacium

Appare Vestigium.Name: Appare Vestigium
Appare Vestigium.Use: Used to reveal and illuminates traces of recent magical activity and shows magical footprints and track marks in an area
Appare Vestigium.Etymology: The spell has two components, appare, a Latin word in the imperative form (present active, second-person, singular meaning 'you appear (now)', a conjugation of the verb appare ('I appear, or come into sight'), and vestigium, Latin for 'footprint or track', or in a broader sense, any from of 'trace, vestige or mark'. Together, the incantation Appare Vestigium can be interpreted as a command, 'footprints, traces, you appear now'.

Apparition.Name: Apparition

Arania Exumai.Use: Used to blast away Acromantulas or other large spiders
Arania Exumai.Etymology: Arania is derived from the Latin word aranea, meaning 'spider'. Exumai is possibly derived from exuo, which is Latin for 'I lay aside' or 'I refused'. Alternatively, the Pronunciation of exumai is somewhat similar to that of exime, a conjugation of eximo, which is Latin for 'I banish'. Together, the incantation can mean 'I lay aside the spider' or 'I banish the spider'.
Arania Exumai.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (first appearance) (non-canonical appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film) (disc 2)

Arresto Momentum.Name: Arresto Momentum
Arresto Momentum.Use: Used to slow the velocity of an object
Arresto Momentum.Etymology: Likely the combination of two words: the Anglo-French 'arester', meaning 'to bring to a stop', and the Latin 'Momentum', meaning 'the force or strength gained whilst moving'. Literal translation: 'bring its momentum to a stop'.
Arresto Momentum.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (first mentioned), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film) (first appearance) (first identified as Arresto Momentum), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay (first identified as Slowing Charm), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Ascendio.Name: Ascendio

Ascendio.Etymology: 'Ascendio' comes from the Latin word 'ascendo', meaning 'to climb'.
Ascendio.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film) (first appearance (Non-canonical appearance), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay, Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Avada Kedavra.Name: Avada Kedavra
Avada Kedavra.Use: When cast, this curse causes instantaneous and painless death
Avada Kedavra.Etymology: Avada Kedavra is derived from Aramaic, avada kedavra meaning 'let the thing be destroy'. J.K. Rowling confirmed this during an audience interview at the Edinburgh Book Festival on April 15, 2004, where she had this to say about the spell's Etymology: 'Does anyone know where avada kedavra came from? It is an ancient spell in Aramaic, and it is the original abracadabra, which means 'let the thing be destroyed'. Originally, it was used to cure illness and the 'thing' was the illness, but I decided to make it the 'thing' as in the person standing in front of me. I take a lot of liberties with things like that. I twist them round and make them mine.'
Avada Kedavra.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance) (appears in flashbacks), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film) (appears in flashbacks), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film( (Avada only), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first identified as the Killing Curse), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film), Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2017 edition) (mentioned only), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay, Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Avensegium.Name: Avensegium
Avensegium.Use: Turns a target object into a tracking device
Avensegium.Etymology: The incantation Avenseguim is likely derived from the portmanteau of avens, a Latin adjective for 'eager' or 'craving', and seguir, the Spanish and Portuguese verb meaning 'to follow', or alternatively from the Catalan seguim, meaning 'we follow'. Taken together, Avenseguim can be interpreted as 'to eagerly follow', which aptly characterizes the behavior of a tracking device
Avensegium.Appearances: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay, Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Expecto Patronum.Name: Expecto Patronum
Expecto Patronum.Use: Used to evoke a partially-tangible positive energy force known as a Patronus or spirit Guardian; primarily used to protect against Dementors and Lethifolds, against which there is no other defence
Expecto Patronum.Etymology: Patronus is the nominative singular case meaning 'protector', 'guardian', or simply 'patron'. In Latin, specifically reflecting the entire role that the Patronus Charm plays. In archaic Latin, it means 'father', which is very interesting, considering that Harry Potter's Patronus is the same as his father's Patronus and Animagus form, a stag. The Latin word exspecto is the first person, singular form of expectare meaning 'to await', thus the charm's incantation translates into 'I await a patron' (since patronum is the singular accusative form of patronus, meaning it is the case which a noun or an adjective describing the noun takes when it is the direct object of a sentence, which in the spell's translation, it is)
Expecto Patronum.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)

Finestra.Name: Finestra

Given Rowling's use of puns in the construction of other incantations (e.g. Orchideous and Aguamenti), it is also possible that finestra is a sort of double entendre - a humorous blend of fine or finis, the Italian and Latin words for 'end', and finestra for window. Together, this could allude to the spell's ironic capacity to destroy windows in the creation of an opening or 'window'.

Mobililarbus.Name: Mobililarbus

Mobililarbus.Etymology: From the Latin word mobililis, meaning 'movable', and arbor, meaning 'tree'.
Mobililarbus.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film) (mentioned only)

Mobilicorpus.Name: Mobilicorpus

Molliare.Name: Molliare
Molliare.Use: Used to create a cushioning effect on the target

Disintegration Spell.Name: Disintegration Spell
Disintegration Spell.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film) (first appearance) (non-canonical appearance)

Mosmordre.Name: Mosmordre
Mosmordre.Use: Used to conjure the image of the Dark Mark, the skull-and-serpent sign used by Voldemort and his Death Eaters
Mosmordre.Etymology: The incantation of this spell appears to be derived from the Latin mors, 'death', and mordere, 'to bite'. This alludes to the name of Voldemort's followers, the Death Eaters. Another derivation may come from French mort, 'death', and mordre, 'to bite'. The English word murder could also contribute. The literal translation of the Norwegian word 'morsmodre' would be 'mothers killers'. It may also be a reference to the word 'mord', which means 'murder' in Icelandic, German, Norwegian, Danish Polish and Swedish, since the spell is cast after someone has been murdered, and sounds like 'mass murder' and 'mortal.'
Mosmordre.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film) (seen in the Daily Prophet) (heard), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film)

Mucus ad Nausedam.Name: Mucus ad Nausedam
Mucus ad Nausedam.Use: Used to give the recipient a nasty cold and an extremely runny nose that can cause the victim to collapse if it is not treated
Mucus ad Nausedam.Etymology: 'Ad Nausedam' is a Latin term meaning 'to the point of nausea'. This implies that the curse makes one produce mucus to the point of them feeling physically ill
Mucus ad Nausedam.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first mentioned), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (mentioned only

Muffliato.Name: Muffliato

Mutatio Skullus.Name: Mutatio Skullus

Nox.Name: Nox

Nox.Etymology: In Latin, 'nox' means 'night'. Nox is also the name of the Roman Goddess of night derived from Nyx (Greek goddess of darkness and night)
Nox.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film) (cut from final edit), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows

Nebulus.Name: Nebulus

Oculus Reparo.Name: Oculus Reparo
Oculus Reparo.Etymology: The word reparo is the first person singular form of the first conjugation verb (-are) reparare, meaning 'to renew' or 'to revive' in Latin. The word oculus is the nominative singular form of the word meaning 'eye'. Thus, the spell Oculus Reparo roughly means 'I renew the eye'. Unfortunately, from a grammatical point of view, this statement is incorrect, because although it follows the common SOV word order, the word oculus is in the nominative singular case, when it should be accusative singular, as it is the object of the sentence.
Oculus Reparo.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film) (first identified as Oculus Reparo) (non-canonical appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (non-canonical appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire

Obliviate.Name: Obliviate

Papyrus is one of the oldest forms of 'paper' known, dating back to ancient Egypt. Reparo is the incantation of the Mending Charm, derived from the Latin verb 'I restore, or repair'.

Petrificus Totalus.Name: Petrificus Totalus

Totalus likely comes from 'Total', meaning complete or wholly. Following this, the spell likely means, entirely petrify.

Protean Charm.Name: Protean Charm

Protean Charm.Etymology: The English word Protean derives from Proteus, a god in Greek mythology. Proteus was a shape-shifter, able to take many forms. As a result, the word Protean has come to refer to versatility, flexibility, or an ability to assume many forms. 'Protean' is also similar to 'protein', derived from the same root, meaning a variable, flexible substance which forms strong bonds between its constituent parts.

Sectumsempra.Name: Sectumsempra
Sectumsempra.Use: Used to lacerate the target and cause severe hemorrhaging
Sectumsempra.Etymology: The incantation Sectumsempra derives from the two Latin words: sectum, a participle of the verb sĕco , 'to cut', and semper, meaning 'always' or 'ever'. Since English has many words meaning 'cut' or 'lacerate', and since spell-names lend themselves to both infinitive and gerund verb forms ('to cut' and 'cutting'), Sectumsempra can be translated in more than one way: 'cut always', 'ever cutting', 'always sever', 'ever severing', and so forth.'Sever' for sectum may be regarded as a particularly appealing translation in that 'sever' creates a pun on Snape's first name, Severus'.
Sectumsempra.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance) (appears in flashback(s)), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first identified as Sectumsempra), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film) (indirectly mentioned only) (effect only), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film) (possible appearance)

Shooting Spell.Name: Shooting Spell
Shooting Spell.Use: Used to create a small explosion with a gun-shot sound
Shooting Spell.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (first appearance) (appears in a deleted scene(s))

Smashing Spell.Name: Smashing Spell
Smashing Spell.Use: Used to cause a huge explosion that ravages and devastates everything in its range
Smashing Spell.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (first appearance) (non-canonical appearance)

Serpensortia.Name: Serpensortia
Serpensortia.Use: Used to conjure a live stanke from the end of the wand
Serpensortia.Etymology: Serpens is Latin for 'serpent'; ortus is the past participle of the Latin verb oriri 'to be created'. In Spanish, serpiente means 'snake or serpent'. In French, sortir is a verb that means to go out, in this case, the snake goes out of the wand.
Serpensortia.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay (possible appearance), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film) (possible appearance

Silencio.Name: Silencio
Silencio.Use: Used to render a victim temporarily mute
Silencio.Etymology: The incantation 'silencio' is Latin and Spanish for 'silence'.
Silencio.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (possible appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film)

Slugulus Eructo.Name: Slugulus Eructo
Slugulus Eructo.Use: Used to force a victim to burp up slugs
Slugulus Eructo.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the CHamber of Secrets (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only) (first identified as Slug-Vomiting Charm), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (mentioned only)

Specialis Revelio.Name: Specialis Revelio
Specialis Revelio.Use: Used to reveal any spells performed on objects of potions
Specialis Revelio.Etymology: In Latin, specialis meaning 'particular; individual' and revelare (present tense revelo) meaning 'unveil'. Altogether the incantation may read as '[to] reveal the particulars [of]
Specialis Revelio.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince) (first appearance)

Stinging Hex.Name: Stinging Hex
Stinging Hex.Use: Used to sting the victim's flesh, producing a red brand like a scorch mark and causes swelling
Stinging Hex.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Deathly, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1

Stupefy.Name: Stupefy
Stupefy.Use: Used to stun a target, rendering them unconscious
Stupefy.Etymology: 'Stupefy' comes from Latin word stupere, meaning 'to be stunned'. Stupefy is also an English word, which means 'to stun' or 'to amaze'.
Stupefy.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first identified as Stunning Spell), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly: Part (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film)

Supersensory Charm.Name: Supersensory Charm
Supersensory Charm.Use: Used to give the target enhanced senses, allowing them to more easily perceive their surroundings
Supersensory Charm.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (first mentioned)

Surgito.Name: Surgito
Surgito.Etymology: Surgita is a Latin word in the imperative form meaning 'you/he/she shall arise, or get up, and is a conjugation of the verb surgo ('I arise').
Surgito.Appearances: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay (first appearance), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Switching Spell.Name: Switching Spell
Switching Spell.Use: Used to switch the positions of two objects
Switching Spell.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first mentioned), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only), Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them: The Original Screenplay (possible appearance), Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film) (possible appearance)

Taboo.Name: Taboo
Taboo.Use: Used to designate a word as a key to revealing the speaker's location
Taboo.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film)

Tarantallegra.Name: Tarantallegra
Tarantallegra.Use: Used to make a target's legs spasm wildly out of control, making it appear as though they were dancing
Tarantallegra.Etymology: The Tarantella is a dance originating in Italy. It was believed to cure the effects of the bite of a Tarantula by causing the victim to sweat out the toxin. It wasn't until centuries later that scientists determined the Black Widow was actually the venomous spider in question; people merely blamed the Tarantula because of its size.[12] Allegra may be derived from allegro, a musical tempo meaning 'quick and lively'; or simply from the word 'leg' as this is the only body part affected by the charm.
Tarantallegra.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (possible appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix

Teapot to Tortoise Spell.Name: Teapot to Tortoise Spell
Teapot to Tortoise Spell.Use: Used to transform a teapot to a tortoise
Teapot to Tortoise Spell.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (first appearance)

Teeth-Straightening Spell.Name: Teeth-Straightening Spell
Teeth-Straightening Spell.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first mentioned) (early drafts)

Teleportation Spell.Name: Teleportation Spell
Teleportation Spell.Use: Used to vanish objects which then appear elsewhere
Teleportation Spell.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (mentioned only)

Tergeo.Name: Tergeo
Tergeo.Use: Used to siphon liquids such as blood, dust or grease in order to clean objects
Tergeo.Etymology: In Latin, the verb tergere means 'to rub off, wipe off, wipe dry, wipe clean, cleanse'.
Tergeo.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows

Titillando.Name: Toenail-Growing Hex
Titillando.Use: Used to cause a victim's toenails to grow at an alarmingly fast rate
Titillando.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance)

Transmogrifian Torture.Name: Transmogrifian Torture
Transmogrifian Torture.Use: Used to torture its victims to death overtime (presumably)
Transmogrifian Torture.Etymology: Transmogrifian comes from the English 'transmogrify', meaning 'to change or alter greatly, often to grotesque effect', possibly implying that the curse changes the shape of the victim to cause pain.
Transmogrifian Torture.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first mentioned), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)

Twitchy-Ears Hex.Name: Twitchy-Ears Hex
Twitchy-Ears Hex.Use: Used to cause a victim's ears to twitch
Twitchy-Ears Hex.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance)

Unbreakable Charm.Name: Unbreakable Charm
Unbreakable Charm.Use: Used to make an object unbreakable
Unbreakable Charm.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first mentioned)

Unbreakable Vow.Name: Unbreakable Vow
Unbreakable Vow.Use: Used as a binding magical contract cast between two parties, that if broken by either party, will result in the imminent death of whoever broke the contract
Unbreakable Vow.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay, Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald

Unsupported Flight.Name: Unsupported Flight
Unsupported Flight.Use: Used to allow the caster to fly without the use of a broomstick or other form of support
Unsupported Flight.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosophers (film) (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film)

Vacuum Cleaner Spell.Name: Vacuum Cleaner Spell
Vacuum Cleaner Spell.Use: Used to clean any object using the caster's wand like a vacuum cleaner
Vacuum Cleaner Spell.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince

Ventus.Name: Ventus
Ventus.Use: Used to shoot a jet of strong, spiralling wind from the top of the caster's wand
Ventus.Etymology: Ventus is a Latin word, meaning 'wind'.
Ventus.Appearances: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay (first appearance), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Vera Verto.Name: Vera Verto
Vera Verto.Use: Used to transform an animal into a water goblet
Vera Verto.Etymology: Vera is taken from the Latin noun Fera meaning 'beast' or 'wild animal'. Verto, also Latin, is a verb that can mean 'I turn' or 'I exchange'. Collectively, Fera Verto is a Latin phrase that can be taken to mean 'I exchange the beast'.
Vera Verto.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (first appearance)

Vermillious.Name: Vermillious
Vermillious.Use: Used to set off a jet of red spark from the tip of the caster's wand
Vermillious.Etymology: Vermillious derives from the English vermillion, a team for a shade of brilliant red. Interestingly, the incantation has two letter 'L's', but the proper spelling of vermilion has only one 'L'.
Vermillious.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (possible appearance)

Vipera Evanesca.Name: Vipera Evanesca
Vipera Evanesca.Etymology: Vipera is a genus of venomous vipers, a Type of snake. Evanesca likely shares its origin with Evanesco, which means 'disappear' in Latin -- Evanesca would be the imperative form of the verb, making this incantation a command for the serpent to disappear, meaning 'Viper, disappear.'
Vipera Evanesca.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (first identified as Vipera Evanesca), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows

Vulnera Sanentur.Name: Vulnera Sanentur
Vulnera Sanentur.Use: Used to heal deep wounds which could also be used as the counter-curse for the curse Sectumsempra
Vulnera Sanentur.Etymology: Vulnera Sanentur derives from the Latin vulnus 'wound', (in which the roots of the English 'vulnerable' may be seen)[7] and sanare, 'to heal'; it is translated 'may the wounds be healed'.
Vulnera Sanentur.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (possible appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood (film) (first identified as Vulnera Sanentur)

Waddiwasi.Name: Waddiwasi
Waddiwasi.Use: Used to propel a small wad of material at high velocity
Waddiwasi.Etymology: 'Waddiwasi' comes from two words. 'Vadd' and 'vas-y'. 'Vadd' is a Swedish word that can mean 'wadding' and 'vas-y' is French term that means 'go ahead' or 'Come on!' Together, they can roughly mean 'The wad goes ahead.'
Waddiwasi.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban

Washing Up Spell.Name: Washing Up Spell
Washing Up Spell.Use: Used to enchant dirty dishes to wash themselves
Washing Up Spell.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)

Wingardium Leviosa.Name: Wingardium Leviosa
Wingardium Leviosa.Use: Used to make objects fly or levitate
Wingardium Leviosa.Etymology: Wingardium is a composite word, based on: English to wing meaning 'to fly' (e.g. the plane winged skywards);arduus (meaning 'high, tall, lofty, steep, proudly elevated') or arduum (meaning 'steep place, the steep'); and the common Latin ending -ium. Leviosa probably derives from Latin levo, meaning to 'raise, lift up', or levis, meaning light (of weight).[31][34] Altogether, therefore, the incantation could best be read as 'lift up high'.
Wingardium Leviosa.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Order of Phoenix (film) (possible appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (possible appearance), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2
